course.subject: MATH
course.name: Financial Economics in Actuarial Science
course.description: The course aims to study some actuarial models and their applications in derivative pricing and financial risk management. Topics include introduction to various derivatives such as forward, futures, European/ American options, exotic options and interest rate derivatives, uses of various options strategies in portfolio management, pricing options using binomial tree model, Black Scholes formula for options pricing and its extension, Options Greeks and their applications in hedging, use of Monte Carlo simulation in options pricing, pricing of interest rate derivatives using the Black-Derman-Toy tree. The course also prepares students to take the Exam MFE (Models for Financial Economics) of the Society of Actuaries.
course.prerequisites: (MATH 2421 OR MATH 2431) AND MATH 2511

reviews.author: Admah
reviews.comment_content: In the first part of this course, we first explore various financial derivatives (forward contract, future contract,options etc.) that are commonly traded in financial market and examine their role in investment/risk management. Next, we examine basic principle (known as no arbitrage pricing principle) for pricing these derivatives. In the second part of this course, we develop several mathematical models for pricing some complex derivatives. For this semester, binomial tree pricing model (discrete-time model) and the famous Black-Scholes model (continuous time model) is covered. Besides the standard no arbitrage pricing principle, we also develop an equivalent pricing approach (known as risk neutral valuation principle) which provides a shortcut in pricing derivatives. If time permits, we also examine some computational algorithm (lattice tree approximation method, Monte-Carlo simulation)that are useful in derivative pricing but these part are not examined. Overall, this course covers the second part of syllabus covered in the Exam IFM(Investment and Financial Market, Items 6-10) of the Society of Actuaries.

Really appreciate his efforts on teaching and i'd suggest you attend every lecture since you'll definitely learn something from his course as long as you put in some efforts.

reviews.author: hiauntie
reviews.title: LCM = Good Grade (work hard plz)
reviews.comment_content:
There are four chapters:
1. Introduction to Financial derivatives
2. Binomial tree pricing models
3. Black-Scholes option pricing model
4. Interest rate derivatives
p.s. There is no time to teach the last chapter

For students who want to take SOA exam MFE (now IFM), this course only cover 60-70% of MFE, you should study by yourself about other parts (e.g. option elasticity, pricing formula for exotic options, interest rate tree etc.)
reviews.comment_teaching: The notes were well-written as always. There are a lot of examples for students to get familiar with the topics. You are highly recommended to attend every class because if too many students miss the class, LCM will be unhappy and the final exam will be "harder". So, please make LCM happy during the class. LCM taught really well (jot notes if you are not smart enough).
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading. If you get along well with LCM and you final score is not bad, B range should not be a problem.

10% Assignment
25% Midterm
65% Final

I got over 70% at the end and got A- (depends on the "curve")
reviews.comment_workload: One assignment for one chapter so workload is not heavy. There are bonus problems to earn extra points toward final points which can help you for grading so I highly recommend you to finish all the bonus problems.

reviews.title: Everything you need to know about basic equity derivative pricing
reviews.comment_content:
Ch 1. Introduction to Financial derivatives
- Forward Contract
- Pre-paid Foward
- Properties of Option
- Brief introduction to American Option

Ch 2. Binomial tree pricing models
- No Arbitrage Pricing Principle
- Dynamical Portfolio Replication
- Risk-Neutral Valuation Principle
- Path-dependent Options (e.g. Asian Option, Lookback Option, Barrier Option)
- CRR Model
- Foward Tree Model
Ch 3. Black-Scholes option-pricing model
- Introduction to stochastic calculus (Ito's Lemma and Properties of stochastic integrals)
- Black-Scholes Equation
- Risk-Neutral Valuation Principle
- Option Greeks and hedging strategies (Delta and Gamma)
- Other Derivatives: Convertable Bonds, Defaultable bonds, Foward Start Option, Chooser Option, Path-dependent derivatives, Digital option, Futures Option

Ch 4.Numerical Algorithms for Black-Scholes model
- Monte Carlo simulation
- Lattice Tree Algorithm

Both Ch 2 and 3 will include dividend-paying asset (discrete/continuous case)

After taking this course, I believe that you can price most of the equity-based derivatives using the techniques taught in this course. There will be some other type of derivatives in the exam e.g. inline warrant, Option on Option etc, and you will be asked to price those option given the derivative structure.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think most of you have familiar with LCM teaching after taking 2511 or 4512, so I don't mention it again, you may go to my review on 4512 for more details.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% Assignment
75% Final

Cutoff (based on the information given in the first lecture)
40% & final >= 25/100 => Pass (C- or above)
62% => B- or above
80% => A- or above
90% => A+ or above


As usual, there are bonus mark (around 50-60 marks) for each assignment and the conversion rate this semester is 30 Bonus mark -> 1% Total

The final exam is easier than expected, at least much easier than last year exam from my perspective.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 Assignments in total,  each may take you a whole day or at least 4-5 hours to finish

The final exam can be quite tricky and the given time is very tight, so make sure you have done enough revision and at least get familiar with the examples in the lecture notes and Assignments before taking the exam.
